I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) a proposed 
loan and (ii) a proposed grant, both to the Kingdom of Cambodia for subprogram 4 of the 
Financial Sector Program II (FSP II). 
 
2.  The development framework for Cambodia’s finance sector is based on the 10-year 
rolling blueprint, last updated and adopted by the government in February 2007 as the Financial 
Sector  Development  Strategy  2006–2015.  Through  the  first  Financial  Sector  Program 1                
2001–2007 of the Asian Development Bank (ADB), the government was able to lay the legal 
and  regulatory  foundations  necessary  for  a  sound,  market-oriented  finance  sector.                        
The government also took strong measures to consolidate the banking system and introduce 
more stringent requirements for capital adequacy, governance, and risk management. With 
significant results achieved from the first FSP, and to ensure the durability of its reform program 
and  inclusive  access  to  financial  services  by  ordinary  citizens,  the  government  requested 
continuing ADB support to the sector. This led to the design and approval of the FSP II in 2007.2 
Comprising a series of four single-tranche subprograms, the FSP II commenced in September 
20063 and will be completed in December 2010 at the conclusion of subprogram 4. The FSP II 
has helped to strengthen resilience, improve public confidence and financial intermediation, 
promote good governance, and enhance efficiency in Cambodia's finance sector. 
 
II.  THE PROGRAM 
 
A.  Rationale 
 
  3.  Inclusive economic growth for poverty reduction. Cambodia’s real gross domestic 
product grew strongly at about 9.1% per year on average from 1998 to 2008. This robust 
economic performance was led by the private sector, particularly in garments, tourist-related 
services, construction, and agriculture, with a substantial proportion being financed from foreign 
direct  investments  and  the  domestic  financial  system.  With  a  rapidly  growing  commercial 
economy that requires a sound financial system to sustain its rate of growth, the government is 
committed to long-term development of the finance sector, channeling financial resources to 
productive  investments,  and  managing  the  inherent  risks  to  achieve  long-term  sustainable 
economic growth and indirectly contribute to poverty reduction. The Asian financial crisis of the 
late 1990s and the global financial crisis that began in 2008 devastated many economies by 
wiping out several years of growth within a very short time. To promote sustainable economic 
growth, reduce poverty, and help to mitigate shocks emanating from external financial crises, 
ADB plays an important role in supporting finance sector development in its developing member 
countries, including Cambodia.

4.  Aligning government commitment to reform with ADB strategy. The government’s 
commitment to developing the finance sector is outlined in the 5-year National Strategy and 
Development  Plan  2006–2010  and  the  Rectangular  Strategy  (phase  2)  of  2008.                      
The government’s vision in the Financial Sector Development Strategy 2006–2015 provides a 
long-term  strategy  and  a  delineated  framework  of  reforms.  In  line  with  the  priorities  and 
strategies  identified  in  the  government’s  National  Strategy  and  Development  Plan  and 
Rectangular Strategy (phase 2), ADB’s country strategy and program focuses on three strategic 
pillars:  (i)  broad-based  economic  growth  through  investments  in  physical  infrastructure, 
development  of  the  finance  sector,  support  for  greater  regional  integration,  sustainable 
development  of  small  and  medium-sized  enterprises,  and  investments  in  agriculture  and 
irrigation; (ii) inclusive social development; and (iii) good governance.4 ADB’s country strategy 
and  program  specifically  states  that  ADB  will  continue  its  leading  role  in  finance  sector 
development as it is one of the five core areas that best supports ADB's Strategy 20205 and its 
goal to reduce poverty in Cambodia. 
 
5.  Promoting inclusive finance for poverty reduction. ADB has supported reforms in 
Cambodia's finance sector since 1999. The program loan cluster approach under the first FSP 
was successful as it provided effective and flexible ways of converting complex policy objectives 
into implementable policy actions. Following on from the first FSP, the FSP II cluster enabled 
the government to continue strengthening the finance sector and to introduce a combination of 
legal  and  regulatory  reforms,  target  capacity  building,  improve  disclosure  standards  and 
financial transparency, and establish key financial infrastructure, including the payments and 
settlement system. Finance sector development helps to reduce poverty by lowering transaction 
costs of economic activities and extending the outreach of the formal finance sector to the poor 
and  to  rural  microenterprises.  While  an  efficient  financial  system  promotes  private  sector 
development and foreign direct investment, a robust finance sector protects the economy from 
unfavorable  exogenous  shocks,  which  are  becoming  more  common  in  increasingly  global 
financial markets, thus reducing the likelihood of falling into poverty again.     
 
B.  Impact and Outcome 
 
6.  The overall impact of the FSP II is a sound, market-based finance sector to enhance 
resource mobilization and support sustainable economic growth. The expected outcome is a 
growing, resilient, and efficient financial system. The design and monitoring framework for the 
program is in Appendix 1; a list of linked documents is in Appendix 2. The development policy 
letter  for  the  FSP  II  cluster  is  in  Appendix  3.  The  policy  actions  for  subprogram  4  and            
medium-term  program  with  a  post-program  partnership  framework  are  in  Appendix  4.                   
With changing domestic circumstances and developmental priorities, the government requested 
minor  modifications  to  two  of  the  triggers.  These  were  endorsed  by  ADB  management              
(footnote 1 in Appendix 4).  
 
C.  Outputs 
 
7.  Continuing the reforms initiated under subprograms 1, 2, and 3, subprogram 4 has nine 
key reform actions (triggers) that the government began implementing in January 2010. All have

5  ADB. 2008. Strategy 2020:  The Long-Term Strategic Framework of the Asian Development Bank, 2008–2020.

3 
been  completed  before  circulating  the  loan  document  to  the  Board.  At  the  conclusion  of 
subprogram 4, the following outputs will have been accomplished under the FSP II cluster: 
 
   1.  Improved Confidence and Financial Intermediation 
 
8.  Modernized  payments,  clearance,  and  settlement  system.  The  process  for 
modernizing the national payments, clearance, and settlement system (PCSS) started in 2006 
when the National Bank of Cambodia (NBC) established the Payments Policy Unit (PPU).     
With technical assistance (TA) from ADB, the NBC developed a road map for modernizing the 
national PCSS and, under subprogram 1, signed a memorandum of understanding with each 
commercial bank endorsing the road map. Key actions of phase I of the road map were 
implemented by the NBC under subprogram 2 in 2008. These included the issuance of a  
prakas 6 on check standardization and the launch of an interbank switch between four banks 
(since increased to five banks). With a long-term payment expert funded by ADB, the road map 
to modernize the PCSS was updated and adopted under subprogram 3. In addition, an interim 
software  solution  for  check  clearance  was developed  by  the  NBC  Information  Technology 
Division and launched in May 2009, together with a set of rules and procedures to regulate the 
clearance and settlement of checks. 
 
9.  Under subprogram 4, the PPU has worked closely with commercial banks to improve the 
efficiency of check clearance and settlement, resolve issues relating to retail mobile phone 
payments, and identify practical solutions to enhance funds transfer and faster bank settlement. 
To enhance funds transfer and early settlement, the PPU has developed a credit remittance 
payment instrument to be used as (i) a direct funds transfer instrument; (ii) a direct credit 
instrument; and (iii) a direct debit instrument for government salary payment, utility payments, 
and settlement between banks. The credit remittance payment instrument has been discussed 
widely with the Association of Bankers in Cambodia (ABC) and issued by the NBC in August 
2010, together with an accompanied prakas. The NBC has obtained funds ($3.6 million) from 
the Ministry of Economy and Finance (MEF) under the FSP II grant to finance the upgrading of 
the interim software solution to a centralized full-solution software system for clearance and 
settlement of checks. The PPU has prepared the bid documents in close consultation with ADB, 
and the procurement process began in July 2010 with the publication of invitation for bids.        
Two commercial banks have introduced funds transfer to rural areas using mobile phones.       
To regulate and protect all parties, a prakas on third-party processor was issued by the NBC in 
August 2010.  
 
10.  Consumer  access  to  credit  and  market  confidence  enhanced.  The  orderly 
development and expansion of the financial market requires knowledgeable customers and 
competent providers of financial services. Since 2005, all banks have been required to publish 
their audited financial statements to enable the public to make informed judgments regarding 
where to place their deposits and with which banks to transact. The FSP II supported the NBC 
in its efforts to promote bank transparency by requiring all audited financial statements of banks 
as well as new prudential regulations to be published on the NBC website. This was achieved in 
2008 and several banks have since published these annual audited financial reports on their 
own websites. 
 
11.  With close cooperation between the NBC and the ABC, a pilot online credit information 
sharing system (CIS), using negative data, was established in August 2006 under the Small and

4 
Medium Enterprise Development Program.7 A number of actions were taken up through the 
Small and Medium Enterprise Development Program to the end of 2007 to improve the software 
system. At the conclusion of the program in 2007, the FSP II helped familiarize stakeholders 
with the system and addressed necessary changes to the CIS and its management structure to 
enhance effectiveness. During subprogram 2, the NBC continued to help resolve systematic 
issues related to the CIS software and added microfinance institutions (MFIs) to the negative 
CIS  system  during  subprogram  3.  Plans  to  upgrade  the  software  system  to  include  other 
sources of credit data covering both banks and MFIs, and the possibility of corporatizing the 
CIS, was expected to come on stream during subprogram 4. At the beginning of 2010, the ABC 
and the Cambodian MFI association formed a joint venture with an international service provider 
to establish a credit bureau fully owned by the private sector. The NBC retains the regulatory 
role to ensure the cost of services is affordable and to maintain the confidentiality of the shared 
information. 
 
12.  Interbank  market  and  tradable  government  securities  developed.  The  Law  on 
Government Securities was enacted in January 2007 to provide a framework for the efficient 
issuance and management of government securities. Under subprogram 2, the NBC was able 
to establish a registry system and train staff in the functions and operation of the registry.    
When subprogram 3 came on stream, the development of a short-term money market was a 
priority and, to provide liquidity support, the NBC introduced regulations covering an interbank 
repurchase  master  agreement  for  secured  interbank  transactions  in  the  money  market  in 
October  2009.  With  the  advent  of  subprogram  4,  the  NBC  went  further  and  formulated 
regulations that were issued as a prakas in October 2010 to allow the use of NBC certificates of 
deposit as collateral for interbank transactions. Though the framework is in place, banks are 
experiencing high liquidity and are not likely to utilize this facility in 2010. 
 
13.  Outreach  in  the  formal  sector  promoted.  Banking  activities  in  rural  areas  are 
improving, with MFIs providing most of the formal financial services. The formal microfinance 
industry  is  growing  rapidly,  with  credit  growing  from  $92.2  million  at  the  end  of  2006  to               
$339.6 million at the end of June 2010. Rapid expansion of credit has put pressure on the 
sources of funding for MFIs, as most of their capital and debts are generated from overseas 
sources. A review by the Consultative Group to Assist the Poor identified that the development 
of deposit services by MFIs has lagged behind credit services. These issues, such as making 
domestic finance more widely accessible to MFIs, are being addressed by the NBC under the 
FSP  II.  As  a  first  step,  the  NBC  introduced  a  regulation  covering  the  minimum  financial, 
institutional, and managerial requirements for MFIs wishing to collect and intermediate voluntary 
public deposits under subprogram 3. The regulation has, among other things, increased the 
minimum capital requirement from $62,000 to $2.5 million. Four qualified MFIs were granted 
licenses during subprogram 4 and three applications are being processed. Since early 2009,  
the NBC has encouraged individual commercial banks to lend directly to MFIs, and in June 
2010 the NBC reported that seven banks were providing credit to MFIs—two in local currency 
and the other five in US dollars.  
 
2.  Maintained Stability in the Finance Sector   
 
14.  Updated legal and regulatory framework for banks. As part of efforts to strengthen 
prudential supervision, update regulations, and ensure stability, the NBC issued regulations           
                                                 
7  ADB. 2004. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors on a Proposed Loan and

Program. Manila (Loan 2129-CAM).

(i) on large exposures of banks and financial institutions, and (ii) to amend the prakas on 
licensing  of  commercial  and  specialized  banks  under  the  FSP  II.  The  NBC  also  issued 
regulations on (i) fit and proper tests on bank management; (ii) corporate governance for banks 
and financial institutions, and (iii) updated asset classification and provisioning for banks and 
financial institutions. Further, the NBC undertook a comprehensive review of the 1999 Law on 
Banking and Financial Institutions (LBFI) to address the features of a changing domestic market 
and the reality of increasing international economic integration. The review benefited from TA 
provided by ADB (footnote 2) and took into consideration consumer protection, bank secrecy 
provisions to support development of the CIS, procedures for administering distressed and 
insolvent banks, and protection or immunity of bank regulators. A revised and updated LBFI was 
submitted to the Council of Ministers (COM) in October 2009 with the expectation that it would 
be submitted to the National Assembly during subprogram 4. Discussions at the COM began in 
February 2010 before the International Monetary Fund and World Bank 2010 Financial Sector 
Assessment Program began. With additional suggestions emanating from the 2010 Financial 
Sector Assessment Program, the NBC decided to withdraw the revised LBFI to incorporate 
those comments and also revise the law on conduct and organization of the NBC. Both the 
revised laws will be submitted to the COM in 2011.  
 
15.  Strengthened  bank  supervision  capacity  and  measures  adopted  to  sustain 
financial stability. Updating and upgrading skills is a priority area that must be an ongoing 
feature of any program aimed at developing and deepening the financial system. With TA 
of $1.7 million (footnote 2) that was approved together with the FSP II, ADB has been providing 
technical support to upgrade the capacity of NBC's supervision staff and strengthen the NBC’s 
surveillance  capability.  While  ADB  supports  the  bank  on-site  supervision  aspect,  the 
International Monetary Fund provides a resident adviser to develop the off-site capability of the 
NBC. As an indication of the importance that ADB places on the NBC’s work in this area, ADB 
approved TA together with subprogram 2 in 2008 that provided on-the-job guidance to bank    
on-site supervision teams.8 The TA culminated in a detailed review of the six largest commercial 
banks during subprogram 3, and the results of the on-site inspections proved very useful in 
recent analysis of the impact of the global economic crisis on Cambodia’s banking system.   
ADB also approved TA in 2009 to help the government implement the triggers for subprogram 4 
and as part of its continuing capacity support to the NBC.9 The NBC has also introduced 
remedial measures broadly anchored on the FSP II program policy framework, which the NBC 
is closely monitoring, and has put in place stronger sanctions to address potential vulnerabilities 
in the banking system.  
 
16.  Prudential supervision and regulations for microfinance institutions strengthened. 
The NBC has made significant progress in building the regulatory framework for licensing and 
supervising registered MFIs. A division for prudential supervision of MFIs within the Banking 
Supervision Department has been established and several prudential regulations in the form of 
prakas have been issued, such as that to amend the prakas on the licensing of MFIs, and those 
covering MFIs that can mobilize voluntary savings (2007) and the management of foreign 
exchange risks (2008). During the implementation of the FSP II and under ADB TA, staff have 
been trained in the implementation of these regulations, and in off-site and on-site supervision 
techniques (footnotes 2, 8, and 9). With the growing number and size of activities generated by

registered money changers, the NBC issued a code of conduct for implementation during 
subprogram 4. The NBC has conducted a series of workshops to explain the purpose of the

17.  Legal  foundation  to  support  financial  and  commercial  transactions  enhanced.    
For  financial  transactions  to  develop  beyond  basic,  short-term,  and  mainly  cash-based 
transactions, a legal framework for commerce and finance must be developed, updated, and 
implemented. This was one of the achievements of the FSP II when the government adopted 
the Law on Government and Private Sector Securities in 2007. For laws that were recently 
enacted, the adoption of implementing subdecrees was required. The enactment of new laws 
has been followed by the development of training curricula at certain legal faculties to train legal 
practitioners and judges in these new principles. ADB provided technical support (footnote 2) 
to help  the  Ministry  of  Commerce  (MOC) draft  a  new  law  on  commercial  contracts  with 
provisions relating to agencies and franchising. The draft law was submitted to the COM in 
October 2009 and to the National Assembly during subprogram 4.  
 
3.  Promoted Good Governance 
 
18.  International initiatives on anti-money laundering and combating the financing of 
terrorism  promoted.  Recent  moves  to  implement  anti-money  laundering  and  combat  the 
financing of terrorism in Cambodia are directly in line with international deterrence efforts and 
standard governance principles to help build market confidence. The government enacted the 
Law  on  Combating  Money  Laundering  and  the  Financing  of  Terrorism  in  2007  under 
subprogram 1. This was followed by the adoption of prakas covering the appointment of the 
board of directors, the secretary general to head the Cambodian Financial Intelligence Unit 
(CAFIU), and the authority to establish the CAFIU during subprogram 2, followed by the formal 
establishment of the CAFIU during subprogram 3. ADB, the Asia Pacific Group on Money 
Laundering,  the  Australian  Transaction  Reports  and  Analysis  Centre,  the  Bank  Negara 
Malaysia,  and  the  World  Bank  provided  TA  that  helped  the  CAFIU  prepare  the  following 
regulations: (i) internal rules and code of conduct for the CAFIU; (ii) CAFIU’s business plan for 
2010–2012;  (iii) a  strategy  and  implementation  plan  for  initiatives  on  combating  money 
laundering and the financing of terrorism; and (iv) a subdecree on combating money laundering 
and the financing of terrorism, covering all other reporting entities not regulated by the NBC. All 
these regulations have been adopted by the CAFIU board of directors during subprogram 4. 
The CAFIU reported that, of the 69 suspicious transactions reported in 2010, two have been 
passed on to the police for prosecution. 
 
19.  Corporate  governance  and  transparency  in  the  insurance  industry  enhanced.      
To build consumer confidence in insurance as a service, the public must first understand the 
insurance business and the services it can provide. The goal for all participants in the industry is 
to  raise  their  operations  to  international  standards.  Under  subprogram  1,  the  MEF  issued 
regulations on premium rates for fire insurance, and licensing of general and life insurance 
companies. The MEF also issued prakas covering corporate governance and solvency for 
insurance companies in early 2008. A prakas on accounting guidelines for general insurance 
was adopted under subprogram 2 and, with technical support from ADB (footnote 8), the MEF 
worked  closely  with  the  association  of  insurance  companies  to  ensure  the  smooth 
implementation of the reporting standards. The MEF also revised the insurance law which was 
submitted  to  the  COM  during  subprogram  3.  During  subprogram  4,  the  MEF  required  all 
insurance companies to publish their audited financial statements.

7 
 
20.  Commercial  dispute  resolution  mechanism  established.  To  promote  good 
governance in the financial system, the government enacted the law on commercial arbitration 
in 2006. After the COM adopted the subdecree in 2009, a national arbitration center (NAC) was 
established. ADB TA (footnote 2) helped the MOC select the 54 founding members, formulate 
the rules and administrative procedures, prepare a code of conduct for the NAC, and train those 
selected  in  June–July  2010.  There  is  no  specific  legal  requirement  for  arbitrators  to  sit  a 
qualifying examination, and the MOC is awaiting a directive from the prime minister requiring all 
commercial arbitrators to sit the qualifying examination. That would give credibility to the NAC 
and help ensure its future successful operations.  
 
21.  Accounting institutions and professional capacity of members strengthened.  In a 
move to strengthen and increase accounting and auditing capacity and standards, the MEF 
introduced a government-funded scholarship scheme to enable 70 recipients annually to study 
toward becoming members of the Kampuchea Institute of Certified Public Accountants and 
Auditors. These scholarships were initially awarded only to government civil servants but poor 
performance  and  a  high  dropout  rate  in  the  initial  phase  prompted  ADB  to  persuade  the 
government to open the scholarships to the public in the second half of 2006. Selection was to 
be strictly on merit. The MEF reviewed the performance of the certified public accountant 
scholarship program in 2009 and noted that, of the 598 scholarships awarded, only 6 scholars 
had completed the 3.5 years course of study, 376 were continuing, and 216 had dropped out; 
10 students are expected to successfully complete the course in 2010. Two units have been 
identified as the stumbling blocks for most students: United Kingdom Corporate and Business 
Law and United Kingdom Taxation Law. The MEF has proposed to revise both units so that 
local laws will be used instead. During subprogram 4, the MEF introduced 35 scholarships for 
the 2-year certified accounting technician program. 
 
4.  Enhanced Efficiency in the Finance Sector  
 
22.  Key  operating  functions  of  the National  Bank  of  Cambodia  computerized  and 
integrated. The FSP II supported the NBC's efforts to implement an integrated system that 
linked the accounting department to the cash management functions in the issues department, 
the customer account management in the banking operations department, and the foreign 
exchange  transactions  in  the  exchange  management  department.  Under  subprogram  1,          
the NBC adopted the information technology architecture model for a total estimated cost of        
$4.0 million. The MEF allocated a $4.0 million grant to the NBC to finance the new system, 
including the required hardware, and ADB TA (footnote 2) provided two international consultants 
to assist the NBC in procuring, designing, and installing the system. Under subprogram 2,       
the NBC acquired the software and hardware using international bidding. Installation of the 
hardware began during subprogram 3. In July 2009, the final testing of the hardware was 
completed and the operating system, Oracle software, and database were installed. Following 
the  completion  of  product  walk-through  and  functional  training  the  system  went  live  in      
February 2010. The same system has been successfully rolled out to eight NBC branches 
during subprogram 4, and implementation of the branch roll-out plan will continue to early 2011.  
 
23.  Capacity of microfinance institution staff upgraded. Finding adequately trained and 
skilled people to meet the needs of a growing microfinance industry is an ongoing challenge.   
To that end, the FSP II included TA that has helped upgrade the curriculum for the Center for 
Banking Studies, added two specialized training curricula for MFIs, and updated a course on 
money and banking. All three courses were offered in the first semester of 2010, with 150 
students enrolled for each course.

8 
 
D.  Investment and Financing Plans 
 
24.  The Government of Cambodia has requested a loan of $10 million equivalent and a 
grant of $5 million, both from ADB’s Special Funds resources to help finance subprogram 4.  
The loan will have a 24-year term, including a grace period of 8 years, an interest rate of 1.0% 
per annum during the grace period and 1.5% per annum thereafter, and such other terms and 
conditions set forth in the draft financing agreement. 
 
25.  The loan amount for subprogram 4 is based on a number of factors10 that support the 
implementation of reforms under the FSP II. These include the importance attached to the 
reform program by the government, direct administrative and adjustment costs involved in 
design  and  implementation  of  specific  reforms,  Cambodia’s  progress  toward  achieving  the 
targets established in the results framework for the program cluster, and the need to conform to 
the  overall  financing  requirement  during  the  country  program  and  strategy  period.                  
The estimated long-term benefits of the program would far exceed the loan amount.  ADB staff 
estimate11 that the total long term static benefits of the cluster program would be in the vicinity 
of $350.9 million or 3.6% of gross domestic product, highlighting the importance of finance 
sector reforms to the economy. The policy adjustment costs to the Government, statutory 
agencies,  banks  and  financial  institutions  are  conservatively  estimated  at  $53.0  million 
(compared to $45.3 million equivalent for FSP II of which $15 million is for subprogram 4). 
These include the investment, administrative, enforcement and fiscal costs to the Government 
in implementing and enforcing the reforms (estimated at a minimum of $30.5 million).  The 
policy adjustment costs also include the investment, administrative, and increased business 
costs borne by banks and financial institutions for complying with the reforms (estimated at a 
minimum of $22.5 million). The loan will be disbursed in a single tranche upon satisfactory 
completion of all tranche conditions and following loan effectiveness. The proceeds of the 
program loan will be disbursed in accordance with the provisions of ADB's Simplification of 
Disbursement Procedures and Related Requirements for Program Loans. 12 Subprogram 4 will 
provide retroactive financing for eligible expenditures incurred up to 180 days prior to loan and 
grant effectiveness. ADB will retain the right to audit the use of the loan and grant proceeds and 
to verify the accuracy of withdrawal application certification. 
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
26.  The NBC will be the executing agency, and the MEF and MOC will be the implementing 
agencies for subprogram 4. The finance sector steering committee will continue to coordinate 
program implementation among government ministries, agencies, and development partners. 
To ensure timely program implementation, the committee, comprising senior officers from the 
MEF, MOC, and NBC, will meet as required to review progress reports from the technical 
working group, consider pending issues, and propose concrete actions to resolve those issues. 
A senior NBC officer has been appointed as program director to assist the MEF, MOC, and 
NBC  in  coordinating  the  day-to-day  program  and  post-program  partnership  framework 
implementation. The program director will be required to submit to ADB quarterly progress 
reports  on  subprogram  4  and  post-program  partnership  framework  implementation  and  a 
program completion report within 6 months after the closing date of the loan.

III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
 
A.  Economic and Financial 
27.   The  policy-based  program  will  generate  economic  gains  through  the  successful 
implementation of the overall policy actions (footnote 11). The immediate benefits include new 
and increased loans totaling $1.52 billion (15% of gross domestic product), the creation of 
12,100 new jobs, and the opening of 983 new branches of banks and MFIs since 2006.13       
The loan and grant proceeds will provide direct budget support to help defray the costs incurred 
by the government in implementing the program. 
 
B.  Governance 
28.  An assessment of the country’s public financial management systems was carried out to 
better  understand  the  fiduciary  risks  and  determine  appropriate  fiduciary  arrangements  for 
subprogram  4.  Discussions  were  held  with  the  government  during  implementation  of 
subprogram 4 on the funds flow from the NBC to MEF and the contribution of the ongoing public 
financial  management  reform  program 14   to  the  administration  of  loan  proceeds. 15                        
The government continues to place significant emphasis on strengthening the overall public 
financial management system, internal control systems, and the functions of the National Audit 
Authority, which have helped lower the fiduciary risk of the public financial management system 
as a whole. Subprogram 4 includes measures to (i) improve the management information 
system and reporting standards within the NBC, banks, insurance firms, and MFIs; (ii) promote 
transparency of information released by banks, MFIs, and insurance firms; (iii) establish a credit 
bureau;  (iv)  support  implementation  of  anti-money-laundering  regulations;  and  (v)  deter 
activities that could support the financing of terrorism. Satisfactory progress has been noted in 
revenue collections, with greater use of the banking system to streamline revenue collection and 
payments processes. 
 
29.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with the government. Consistent with its commitment to good governance, accountability, and 
transparency, the government will institute, maintain, and comply with internal procedures and 
controls following international best practice standards for the purpose of preventing corruption 
or money laundering activities or the financing of terrorism, and covenant with ADB to refrain 
from engaging in such activities. 
 
C.  Poverty, Social, Gender, and Environmental Safeguards 
30.  Subprogram  4  of  the  FSP  II  will  not  entail  any  involuntary  resettlement  or  have  a 
negative  impact  on  indigenous  people  or  the  environment.  It  is  classified  category  C  for 
involuntary  resettlement,  impact  on  indigenous  people,  and  impact  on  the  environment. 
Subprogram 4 of the FSP II is a general intervention aimed at supporting sustainable economic 
growth. In that respect, it is expected to have an indirect positive effect on poverty reduction. 
While the implementation of reform measures have been gender neutral, the NBC reported that

D.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
31.  Subprogram  4  of  the  FSP  II  assumes  continuing  political  stability  and  overall 
macroeconomic  recovery  from  the  global  economic  shock  over  the  medium  term. 
Implementation of subprogram 4 could face a number of risks, however, for which mitigation 
measures have been put in place (risk assessment and risk management plan).16 With the 
design safeguards, the integrated benefits and impacts are expected to far outweigh any costs. 
 
IV.  ASSURANCES 
32.  The government and the NBC have assured ADB that the implementation of the FSP II 
cluster shall conform to all applicable ADB policies including those concerning anticorruption 
measures,  safeguards,  gender,  procurement,  consulting  services,  and  disbursement  as 
described in detail in the program loan and grant documents. In addition, the government has 
given the following specific assurances, which will be incorporated into the financing agreement: 
the  government  will  (i)  continue  timely  policy  dialogue  on  a  regular  basis  with  ADB  on 
macroeconomic policies and constraints; (ii) keep ADB informed of policy discussions with other 
multilateral and bilateral agencies that have implications for the implementation of subprogram 
4, the post-program partnership framework, and the overall program cluster; and (iii) provide 
ADB with an opportunity to comment on any resulting policy proposals. The government will 
take ADB’s views into consideration before finalizing and implementing any such proposals. 
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
33.  I  am  satisfied  that  the  proposed  loan  and  grant  would  comply  with  the  Articles  of 
Agreement of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  recommend that  the Board approve

Cambodia  for  subprogram  4  of  the  Financial  Sector  Program  II  from  ADB’s 
Special Funds resources with an interest charge at the rate of 1.0% per annum 
during the grace period and 1.5% per annum thereafter; for a term of 24 years, 
including a grace period of 8 years; and such other terms and conditions as are 
substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft financing agreement 
presented to the Board; and 
(ii)  the grant not exceeding $5,000,000 to the Kingdom of Cambodia from ADB’s 
Special Funds resources for subprogram 4 of the Financial Sector Program II, on 
terms and conditions that are substantially in accordance with those set forth in 
the draft financing agreement presented to the Board.
